title: DDX27
text:
DEAD (Asp-Glu-Ala-Asp) box polypeptide 27, also known as DDX27, is a human <a href="gene">gene</a>.
The <a href="protein">protein</a> encoded by this gene belongs to the family of DEAD box proteins, characterized by the conserved <a href="structural%20motif">motif</a> Asp-Glu-Ala-Asp (DEAD), and are putative <a href="RNA">RNA</a> <a href="helicase">helicase</a>s. They are implicated in a number of cellular processes involving alteration of RNA <a href="secondary%20structure">secondary structure</a> such as <a href="Eukaryotic%20translation%23Initiation">translation initiation</a>, <a href="cell%20nucleus">nuclear</a> and <a href="mitochondrion">mitochondrial</a> <a href="RNA%20splicing">splicing</a>, and <a href="ribosome">ribosome</a> and <a href="spliceosome">spliceosome</a> assembly. Based on their distribution patterns, some members of this family are believed to be involved in <a href="embryogenesis">embryogenesis</a>, <a href="spermatogenesis">spermatogenesis</a>, and <a href="cell%20growth">cellular growth</a> and <a href="cell%20division">division</a>. This gene encodes a DEAD box protein, the function of which has not been determined.
Model organisms.
<a href="Model%20organism">Model organism</a>s have been used in the study of DDX27 function. A conditional <a href="knockout%20mouse">knockout mouse</a> line, called "Ddx27tm1a(KOMP)Wtsi" was generated as part of the <a href="International%20Knockout%20Mouse%20Consortium">International Knockout Mouse Consortium</a> program, a high-throughput mutagenesis project to generate and distribute animal models of disease to interested scientists.
Male and female animals underwent a standardized <a href="phenotypic%20screen">phenotypic screen</a> to determine the effects of deletion. Twenty seven tests were carried out and two <a href="phenotypes">phenotypes</a> were reported. No <a href="homozygous">homozygous</a> <a href="mutant">mutant</a> embryos were identified during gestation, and in a separate study only 1% survived until <a href="weaning">weaning</a> (significantly less than the <a href="Mendelian%20ratio">Mendelian ratio</a>). The remaining tests were carried out on <a href="heterozygous">heterozygous</a> mutant adult mice; no significant abnormalities were observed in these animals.
